Topic.Title: Yahoo In Talks With Microsoft To Buy Bing

Message.Msg: The revenue deal will be Microsoft's compensation. -Yahoo Search will now be the search engine on all Microsoft sites. - Yahoo will provide the relationship sales force for both companies’ premium search advertisers. - Each company will maintain its own separate display advertising business. - Self-serve advertising for both companies will go through Yahoo's Ad platform. - Yahoo will compensate Microsoft through a revenue sharing agreement on traffic generated on Microsoft’s network.

Message.Title: Alibaba Takes 28% Stake in AutoNavi
Message.Msg: Chinese digital map provider AutoNavi (Nasdaq: AMAP) today announced that the company and several entities affiliated with Chinese e-commerce conglomerate Alibaba Group have agreed to form a strategic alliance to jointly explore and develop location-based e-commerce products. The parties plan to share certain data, including AutoNavi's map data and location-related information of the merchants on Alibaba's e-commerce platforms, including Taobao and TMall. AutoNavi and Alibaba will also cooperate in the areas of map engine, location search, navigation and cloud computing services and will cross-promote their respective products and services, with a goal of developing new location-based business models. Alibaba, through a wholly owned subsidiary, will invest USD 294 mln in newly issued preferred and ordinary shares of AutoNavi, representing approximately 28% of the company's total issued and outstanding shares on a fully-diluted basis. Joseph Tsai, executive vice chairman of Alibaba, and Eddie Wu, president of Alibaba's mobile products division, will join AutoNavi's board of directors upon the closing of the transaction.

Message.Title: Alibaba Shows Net Profit of US$ 642 Mln in Q4
Message.Msg: Beijing) – Alibaba Group turned a net profit of US$ 642 million in the last quarter of 2012, up more than 170 percent compared to the same period a year earlier. The information comes from a document that Yahoo Inc. submitted to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Last summer, Alibaba bought back a 20 percent stake in the company from Yahoo Inc., strengthening the management team's weight in the boardroom. It was the first time that a single quarter's net profit of the e-commerce giant exceeded that of Tencent Holdings Ltd., the largest internet company in the country. Tencent had a net profit of US$ 565 million in the fourth quarter of last year, a company financial report shows, and the figure for rival Baidu Inc. was US$ 449 million. "There is much room to grow for China's online shopping market," industry analyst Wang Guanxiong said. "Being the leader in the e-commerce industry, Alibaba is the biggest beneficiary of the prosperous online shopping market." Jack Ma will step down as Alibaba's chief executive officer on May 10, but he will remain executive chairman. He is also taking on a role with The Nature Conservancy, a non-profit environmental protection organization in the United States. Industry insiders say Alibaba will seek an initial public offering this year. Alibaba once planned to list in the United States and Hong Kong late this year, a company shareholder said. However, that plan will be postponed to mid-2014. Alibaba said on May 10 that it bought a 28 percent stake in AutoNavi Holdings Ltd. for US$ 294 million. The company is a digital map and navigation service provider. Several sources told leading internet portal Sina Corp. the company would become the largest stakeholder in AutoNavi. In a deal that represents the largest equity purchase so far in China's internet industry, Alibaba announced a US$ 586 million investment in Sina Weibo, Sina's Twitter-like service. The investment has widely been viewed as an attempt by Aliba
Bow down when in the presence of your King...

Message.Title: The Longer it Takes for Alibaba to IPO....
Message.Msg: the better it is going to be for YHOO. Alibaba has only begun to tap into the e-commerce boom in China and will continue to amaze with their growth numbers. All that means is that the longer they wait, the fatter Yahoo's 24% stake gets not to mention the $80M they are making in interest off the preferred shares. Wait another year and they will be talking about a $150-$170B Alibaba IPO which translates into a pre-tax value to Yahoo of $40B. Their current market cap is under $30B. Not to mention YJ and their ridiculous growth and Yahoo's 35% stake there. Oh, and let's not forget that Yahoo isn't just a holding company, they actually have a very solid business model that is growing stronger by the day and are reducing float via buybacks. Really, anyone who is actually short YHOO needs to take a quick finance lesson and learn how to read a balance sheet/income statement and will soon realize that you are missing out on a golden opportunity to essentially buy cash at a discount all the way up to $50/sh. With some proven results in Q2/Q3 this year, YHOO will trade in the $70-80 range and don't rule out a HUGE pop when they report next quarter or the one after and some of the moves MM is making translates into GROWTH!!!

Topic.Title: The Longer it Takes for Alibaba to IPO....

Message.Msg: I like your analysis with one concern. My concern is that you have inflated the IPO price that Alibaba is contemplating by a 50-70B. From every article I have seen, Alibaba is genuinely concerned about pulling a 100B+ FB style IPO disaster and will limit the IPO to sub-100B. As a result, I believe YHOO's take would be closer to 24B. Not paltry by any means - nearly doubling its current capitalization. Therefore, I think YHOO will trade following the IPO at a fair value of $52 p/s. Cheers.

Topic.Title: The Longer it Takes for Alibaba to IPO....

Message.Msg: certainly seems to be a concern in the short term but another year of the growth that Alibaba just showed and nobody will be concerned about "another FB". Alibaba is printing money while FB was really a vision of what could be that shouldn't ever have been close to $100B. I don't think one can even compare the 2 and I feel much better about YHOO holding 24% of Alibaba vs. the same % of FB. Anyway, we will see how it plays out but people are slowly starting to realize what we are sitting on here...

Message.Title: WSJ article on Jack Ma. "Weekend Confidential: Jack Ma of Alibaba"
Message.Msg: This article made me chuckle in a few places. Ma is self-depricating, & charming but the crocodile is still alive & well. This section in particular got me laughing. "Mr. Ma also has experience with less successful unions. Last fall, Alibaba bought back half of the 40% stake that Yahoo had owned in the company. When asked why, Mr. Ma responds, "They [Yahoo] changed the CEO how many times?" He leans forward and sways his head from left to right, as if to watch a rapid succession of CEOs. "It's like a Hollywood movie!" he says. "It's like a teen series!" Okay fair enough, the frequent CEO changes were an embarrassment, but two things stand out from his statement. One, Jerry Yang invested a boatload of money at a time when Ma was in need. They are great friends & it could not have been easy seeing his friend Yang being maligned & eventually not only removed as CEO but effectively removed from his own company. The second thing is Ma was desperate to buy back as much of Yahoo!'s stake as possible - between Softbank & Yahoo, 70% of his company was not in his hands. There would have been no possibility of an IPO without him gaining control of a sigificant amount, & it's ALL about the IPO. I don't believe Son gave up any of his stake - did he? Money makes the world go round. Also, highly amused by the statement regarding giving away half of his wealth.

Topic.Title: WSJ article on Jack Ma. "Weekend Confidential: Jack Ma of Alibaba"

Message.Msg: Nice post Basket.
